LPI, Horn of Africa Regional Programme 2017-2021

description.narrative:
Liv-och Fredinstitutet (LPI) har ansökt om medel (39 474 391 SEK) från Sida för att genomföra den andra fasen av "Regionala Programmet för Afrikas Horn" under perioden 2017-2020.
Insatsen syftar till att förbättra policys och åtgärder inom strategiska områden som påverkar människors säkerhet på Afrikas horn. Målet är att inkludera en bred grupp av intressenter och att ta fram evidensbaserade policys för att se till att människors säkerhet prioriteras i regionalpolitik. Programmet planerar att bygga upp kapaciteten hos det civila samhällets aktörer för att dessa på ett effektivt sätt ska kunna delta i den regionalpolitiska processen samt att främja samarbeten mellan statliga och icke-statliga aktörer för bättre policys som inkluderar utmaningar för mänsklig säkerhet i regionen.
Insatsens totala budget uppgår till 70 554 391 SEK och den förväntas att finansieras av Sida (55%), EU (36%), och ”Bread for the World” (9%). För närvarande uppskattar LPI att 35 % av den totala programfonden kommer att vidarebefordras till tredje part; dock kommer största delen av de medel som vidarebefordras täckas av EU-bidraget (som preliminärt accepteras) och resterande kommer att finansieras av Sida och andra givare.

The goal of the intervention is to contribute to improving the policies and actions on strategic issues affecting human security in the horn of Africa. Specifically, it is aimed at promoting multi stakeholder engagement and evidence based policy making to so as to ensure that the human security priorities are reflective of the realities on the ground.

description.narrative: LPI under the Horn of Africa Regional Programme (HARP) has reported some results in 2019. Some of the results are highlighted here. LPI co-produced a simple compendium on IGAD. LPI has been engaged with the IGAD Secretariat’s communications department since 2017, it has been designed as a resource for civil society and other institutions to understand and interact with IGAD and potential entry points. This will build civil society capacity to engage and strengthen IGAD’s outreach to civil society and provide insights to civil society on how they can practically access and collaborate with the regional body; and improve interface between IGAD and civil society. The compendium has been finalised and published. The work of LPI in their Cross-Border Cooperation (CBC) Project has facilitated for 26 borderlands grassroots civil society organisations (CSOs) to engage directly with the African Union (AU) and IGAD to discuss the needs and interests of their communities. It ensures policy makers at the AU and RECs level are aware of human security challenges faced on the ground. As a result of their engagement with the CBC Coalition, the AU Border Programme has requested more regular engagements and begun to engage more with borderland communities outside of the coalition– a marked and attributable change in the action of policymakers. LPI has also furthered relationships with the IGAD Cross Border Development Facilitation Unit (CBDFU) in what IDDRSI refers to as the Karamoja Cluster through providing technical support. The first of several other such units are planned by Drought Disaster Resilience Sustainability Initiative (IDDRSI), the Karamoja CBDFU facilitates cooperation in the implementation of IDDRSI among the four countries (Kenya, Uganda, Ethiopia and South Sudan) that share boundaries in the Karamoja Region. LPI and its partner in Uganda, EASSI, have undertaken in-depth actor mapping of 51 peace and security actors in the Karamoja Cluster (West Pokot, Turkana, Karamoja, Moroto, Taposa, and South Omo) as a foundation for the work of the facilitation unit. This mapping will ensure that IGAD is well equipped with information on the partners working on the different IDDRSI development pillars and hence work towards creating synergies with and amongst the actors. Under the Cross-border Cooperation Project, two CSOs namely, Alliance for Sustainable Health and Wealth in Africa (ASHWA), and Amalgamated General Transport Workers’ Union (ATGWU) through trainings recieved, CSOs operating around cross-border area increased ability to advocate for community needs, engage collaborative relationships and even successfully mobilise resources due to the capacity enhancement trainings on advocacy and organisational development in particular.
